label: Abra: A Living Text
creator: Amaranth Borsuk, Kate Durbin, and Ian Hatcher
doc_source: The Center for Book and Paper Arts
description: Constructed by Amy Rabas at the Center for Book and Paper Arts at Columbia College Chicago with help from graduate students in Inter-Arts, the artists’ book edition of Abra invites readers to see the page itself as an interface that invites touch and interaction. Animating across its surface, the poems mutate in an ecstatic helix of words that blur the boundary between text and illumination.

label: Between Page and Screen
creator: Amaranth Borsuk
doc_source: Otis College of Art and Design
description: Between Page and Screen was printed in an edition of 12 on a Vandercook proof press at Otis College of Art and Design in Los Angeles, California. The book was digitally set in URW Grotesk and hand-printed from photopolymer plates on Rives BFK paper. The three-dimensional poems were set in Helvetica Bold, using the VectorVision library. The binding is Keith Smith's Butterfly, which is also known as Yamato Toji and Double Span-Span Span-Span.

label: Frolic Architecture
creator: Susan Howe
description: Frolic Architecture, a sixty-eight page book, comprises forty-eight collage poems by Susan Howe printed letterpress on Somerset paper at The Grenfell Press by Brad Ewing, and ten photograms printed in James Welling's studio. The book was bound by Claudia Cohen using handmade Izumo Mitsumata-shi and Cave papers.

label: Word & Thread (Palabra e Hilo)
creator: Cecilia Vicuña
description: Edited and designed by Alec Finlay with the author, Word & Thread was published on the occasion of Cecilia Vicuña's exhibition "Precario" at Inverleith House, Royal Botanic Garden, Edinburgh, October 26, 1996 - January 5, 1997.

label: Mardi Gras, 1930s
creator: Louisiana Works Progress Administration
description: B/W photo, 1930s. Street scene during carnival. African Americans, predominently women in costume, dancing and singing in a New Orleans street.

label: Blackberry Vendor

label: Baby Doll Celebration

label: Baby Doll Celebration
creator: Louisiana Works Progress Administration
description: B&W photo, March 19, 1942. Baby Doll Celebration. Part of Mardi Gras in New Orleans, La. Rhythm Club, 300 Jackson Ave. Written on photo: "Black music clubs fostered African American jazz musicians."
